meanings.def: the part of something that remains
examples: Take what you want and throw the rest away.
the rest of something The country enjoys friendly relations with the rest of the world.
How would you like to spend the rest of the day?
for the rest of something I'm not doing this job for the rest of my life.

meanings.def: the people or things that remain; the others
examples: The first question was difficult, but the rest were pretty easy.
the rest of something Don't blame Alex. He's human, like the rest of us.

meanings.def: a period of relaxing, sleeping or doing nothing after a period of activity
examples: I had a good night's rest.
We stopped for a well-earned rest.
rest from something to have/take a rest from all your hard work
Try to get some rest—you have a busy day tomorrow.
There are no matches tomorrow, which is a rest day, but the tournament resumes on Monday.
We stopped for a well-earned rest.
Let’s take a break.
The drug brought a brief respite from the pain.
Take time out to relax by the pool.
This delay gives the party a breathing space in which to sort out its policies.
Get some rest while you can.
Her heart would find no rest until she knew the truth.
I apologize for disturbing your rest.
I had a good long rest before the party.
I need my beauty rest.
I was hospitalized many times and put on bed rest for six months.
The body requires a healthy diet and adequate rest.
The doctor advised him to take a complete rest from football.
You need a rest from all your hard work.

meanings.def: an object that is used to support or hold something
examples: an armrest (= for example on a seat or chair)

meanings.def: a period of silence between notes; a sign that shows a rest between notes
used at the end of a list to mean everything else that you might expect to be on the list
examples: He wants a big house and an expensive car and all the rest of it.

meanings.def: used to say that the actual amount or number of something is much higher than somebody has stated
examples: ‘It cost 250 pounds…’ ‘And the rest, and the rest!’

meanings.def: not moving
examples: At rest the insect looks like a dead leaf.

meanings.def: dead and therefore free from trouble or worry. People say ‘at rest’ to avoid saying ‘dead’.
examples: She now lies at rest in the churchyard.

meanings.def: to stop moving
examples: The car crashed through the barrier and came to rest in a field.
His eyes came to rest on Clara's face.
The ball rolled down the hill and came to rest against a tree.

meanings.def: apart from that; considering other matters
examples: The book has some interesting passages about the author's childhood. For the rest, it is extremely dull.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody to stop talking about something because they are annoying you
examples: Give it a rest! You’ve been complaining all day.

meanings.def: to stop doing something for a while
to bury somebody. People say ‘to lay somebody to rest’ to avoid saying ‘to bury’ somebody.
examples: George was laid to rest beside his parents.

meanings.def: to stop something by showing it is not true
examples: The announcement finally laid all the speculation about their future to rest.

meanings.def: used when somebody is complaining that they have a lot of work to do
to do or say something to make somebody stop worrying about something
used when you are telling a story to say that you do not need to tell the end of it, because everyone knows it already

meanings.def: to relax, sleep or do nothing after a period of activity or illness; to not use a part of your body for some time
examples: The doctor told me to rest.
(figurative) He won't rest (= will never be satisfied) until he finds her.
rest something He had to rest his injured knee for six weeks.
Rest your eyes every half an hour.
He could rest safely in this place.
I stopped to rest on one of the benches.
I awoke feeling rested and refreshed.

meanings.def: to support something by putting it on or against something; to be supported in this way
examples: rest something + adv./prep. Rest your head on my shoulder.
He rested his chin in his hands.
+ adv./prep. Their bikes were resting against the wall.
I settled back, my hands resting in my lap.
She rested the ladder against the wall.
She let his hand rest heavily on hers.
His hands rested lightly on her shoulders.
His hand was resting lazily against the steering wheel.
Her head was resting comfortably against his chest.
His chin rested on his hands.
Her thin hands were resting atop the quilted bed cover.

meanings.def: if you let a matter rest, you stop discussing it or dealing with it
examples: The matter cannot rest there—I intend to sue.
And there the matter rested until an interested journalist uncovered the file.

meanings.def: to be buried. People say ‘rest’ to avoid saying ‘be buried’
examples: She rests beside her husband in the local cemetery.
May he rest in peace.

meanings.def: to relax and stop worrying
examples: You can rest easy—I'm not going to tell anyone.
I can sleep easy knowing that she's safely home.

meanings.def: used to show respect when you are talking about somebody who is dead
used to emphasize that what you say is true or will definitely happen
examples: You may rest assured that we will do all we can to find him.

meanings.def: used to say that you do not need to say any more about something because you think that you have proved your point
used by lawyers in court to say that they have finished presenting their case
examples: The prosecution rests its case.

meanings.def: to feel so satisfied with what you have already achieved that you do not try to do any more

examples: You can rest easy—I'm not going to tell anyone.
I can sleep easy knowing that she's safely home.
